message.content:
We start by “translating” the statements into chains. For instance, the statement

  “Ruth is Rebecca’s ancestor”

means that Ruth is at an earlier generation than Rebecca. In a similar fashion, we note:

  Ruth → Rebecca        (Ruth is an ancestor of Rebecca)
  Rebecca → Noah        (Rebecca is an ancestor of Noah)
  Noah → Henry        (Noah is an ancestor of Henry)
  Henry → Diane        (Henry is an ancestor of Diane)
  Diane → Martha       (Diane is an ancestor of Martha)
  Martha’s descendant is Amanda (“Amanda is Martha’s descendant”).

Thus one family “branch” is:
  Ruth → Rebecca → Noah → Henry → Diane → Martha → Amanda

On the other side, consider the statements that involve Gerald. We see:
  Gerald is Gary’s ancestor, so
  Gerald → Gary
and
  Gary → Jonathan    (“Gary is Jonathan’s ancestor”)
and
  Jonathan → Carol   (“Jonathan is Carol’s ancestor”)
and
  Carol → Arthur    (“Carol is Arthur’s ancestor” because later we also learn “Steven is Arthur’s descendant,” meaning Arthur is above Steven)
Continuing along that chain (by following further relationships provided) we eventually find links moving downward (for example, Arthur’s descendant Steven, then Steven’s descendant Grace, then Grace’s descendant Karen, and so on). An illustrative extraction is:
  Gerald → Gary → Jonathan → Carol → Arthur → Steven → Grace → Karen → … 
Eventually this chain reaches names like Joe, Ann, and George (for example, “Joe is Ann’s ancestor” and “Ann is George’s ancestor”). Thereafter names such as Sara, Mason, and Catherine appear in the line.

Thus the Gerald branch (or the branch in which Gerald acts as an ancestor) is quite long and involves a completely different set of names:
  Gerald → … → Joe → Ann → George → … → (others).

When we compare the two branches we got—
  Ruth’s branch: Ruth, Rebecca, Noah, Henry, Diane, Martha, Amanda
  Gerald’s branch: Gerald, Gary, Jonathan, Carol, Arthur, Steven, Grace, Karen, …, Joe, Ann, George, …, etc.

There is no statement that connects anyone from Ruth’s branch with anyone from Gerald’s branch. In particular, there is no indication that Ruth is an ancestor (or descendant) of Gerald, nor that they share a common descendant or a common ancestor. (Note the “common ancestor” in our given terms would have to be a person who is an ancestor of both Ruth and Gerald—but here Ruth and Gerald are given only as the “roots” of their own respective branches.)

Thus, none of the four given relationship possibilities correctly describe a relationship between Ruth and Gerald.

The correct answer is therefore:

<ANSWER>5</ANSWER>
